awd_titl_txt: Random Structures and Integrable Systems: Analysis and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goal of the projects supported by this award is to develop mathematical tools that can describe the structure and properties of networks and surfaces that model random evolution in random environments. Examples of this are contact processes which model infections that spread by contact with an infected neighbor. Other example are voter models which describe the spread of opinions where an individual's opinions are affected by his or her neighbor's opinions. Other motivations arise from extending methods of statistical mechanics classically done on regular lattices to the setting of random lattices which we may think of as random graphs or networks on a surface. In this work the PI will provide an improved understanding of such models in terms of random metrics. One may imagine these metrics are determined by patterns of disease propagation or social contact. Interestingly the general study of random metrics arose from physical investigations of two-dimensional (2D) quantum gravity.

The central problem of 2D quantum gravity, in mathematical terms, is to rigorously construct a measure on the space of metrics on a Riemann surface. This is a long-standing problem of both geometric and physical relevance. But aside from, and perhaps even beyond this, it serves as a rich source of novel problems and ideas that are at the interface between random structures and integrable systems. The focus of this proposal is on emerging crosscurrents of research between probability theory, with an emphasis on random geometry and combinatorics, and integrable systems theory with an emphasis on classical analysis, complex function theory, dynamical systems and conservative partial differential equations.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching theme of the results achieved with the support of this NSF grant concern the construction of methodological bridges between random combinatorial structures and dynamical systems theory, in particular integrable systems theory. There were two initial motivations for what the PI originally proposed.

The first concerned combinatorial structures related to random surface tilings. In physical applications these are sometimes referred to as foams. They also arise in biological applications related to embryonic cell morphogenesis. The mathematical questions here concern the enumeration of such tilings in which the number of tiles and their valences (number of sides of the tiles) is fixed. Such enumerations are the basis for constructing explicit probability measures on these tilings. With the support of this grant, the PI and his students were able to construct closed form generating functions for the enumerations of such tilings on surfaces of varying genus and showed that they were rational functions of determinate degrees in a certain universal function. The connection to dynamics here was that these functions satisfy a hierarchy of conservative PDE. These PDE are what enable the specific construction of said generating functions.

The second motivation concerned general classes of probability measures on permutations which depend on weights determined by the cycle structure of the permutations and the asymptotic limit of these measures. Such measures have relevance in describing aspects of chemical kinetics and the formation of condensates. In many instances the asymptotic measures have associated distributions that are heavy-tailed. The PI and his collaborators were able to bring to bear techniques of complex function theory, motivated by methods from integrable systems theory, to derive novel methods for proving associated probabilistic limit laws.

These foundational results have opened avenues of research which the PI, along with his students and his collaborators, has continued to pursue under the auspices of the grant. These include:

a) the exploration of random walks on random trees in terms of the dynamics of autonomous Painleve equations;

b) the discovery of a deep connection between special orbits of non-autonomous discrete Painleve equations and the asymptotics of the recurrence coefficients for orthogonal polynomials with exponential weights;

c) the tropical construction of an explicit correspondence between an algorithm for computing the Clebsch-Gordon coefficients of a composite quantum mechanical system and the discrete dynamics of a solitonic box-ball system;

d) constructing explicit solutions of the Yang-Mills-Higgs on a punctured Riemann surface and their relation to problems of current interest in condensed matter physics;

e) mean field Gibbs to non-Gibbs transitions from a Hamilton-Jacobi perspective.

Over the period of the grant the PI has advised and supported 8 graduate students who have all now successfully completed their PhD's. Six of these have now established themselves in careers in the mathematical sciences. The remaining two have just graduated this past summer and are applying for jobs in mathematical fields.
